abstract_summ: Unfortunately, since the imaging characteristics of the COVID-19 infection are diverse and similar to the backgrounds, existing medical image segmentation methods cannot achieve satisfactory performance.However, it remains unclear whether various non-COVID19 lung lesions could contribute to segmenting COVID-19 infection areas and how to better conduct this transfer procedure.However, pure manual segmentation of CT images faces a serious challenge with the increase of suspected cases, resulting in urgent requirements for accurate and automatic segmentation of COVID-19 infections.Amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, researchers have explored and proposed the use of said deep models to detect COVID-19 infections from radiographs as a possible way to help ease the strain on medical resources.Extensive experiments on a COVID-19 infection dataset demonstrate that the proposed Inf-Net outperforms most cutting-edge segmentation models and advances the state-of-the-artThe possibility to use widespread and simple chest X-ray (CXR) imaging for early screening of COVID-19 patients is attracting much interest from both the clinical and the AI community.
title_summ: Investigating Transferability in COVID-19 CT Image Segmentation3D Tomographic Pattern Synthesis for Enhancing the Quantification of COVID-19Lung Infection Quantification of COVID-19 in CT Images with Deep LearningAutomated Chest CT Image Segmentation of COVID-19 Lung Infection based on 3D U-NetEnd-to-end learning for semiquantitative rating of COVID-19 severity on Chest X-raysAn automatic COVID-19 CT segmentation network using spatial and channel attention mechanismRole of Edge Device and Cloud Machine Learning in Point-of-Care Solutions Using Imaging Diagnostics for Population ScreeningSynergistic Learning of Lung Lobe Segmentation and Hierarchical Multi-Instance Classification for Automated Severity Assessment of COVID-19 in CT ImagesPOCOVID-Net: Automatic Detection of COVID-19 From a New Lung Ultrasound Imaging Dataset (POCUS)A Weakly Supervised Consistency-based Learning Method for COVID-19 Segmentation in CT ImagesLearning Diagnosis of COVID-19 from a Single Radiological ImageInf-Net: Automatic COVID-19 Lung Infection Segmentation from CT ImagesTowards Efficient COVID-19 CT Annotation: A Benchmark for Lung and Infection SegmentationResidual Attention U-Net for Automated Multi-Class Segmentation of COVID-19 Chest CT ImagesCOVID-19 Chest CT Image Segmentation -- A Deep Convolutional Neural Network SolutionACCURACY TESTINGOnline COVID-19 diagnosis with chest CT images: Lesion-attention deep neural networksInf-Net: Automatic COVID-19 Lung Infection Segmentation from CT ScansUnveiling COVID-19 from Chest X-ray with deep learning: a hurdles race with small dataIntra-model Variability in COVID-19 Classification Using Chest X-ray ImagesEvaluation of Contemporary Convolutional Neural Network Architectures for Detecting COVID-19 from Chest RadiographsDoes Non-COVID19 Lung Lesion Help?Deep learning models for COVID-19 infected area segmentation in CT imagesTRACKING AND PREDICTING COVID-19 RADIOLOGICAL TRAJECTORY USING DEEP LEARNING ON CHEST X-RAYS: INITIAL
title_abstract_phrases: Unfortunately, since the imaging characteristics of the COVID-19 infection are diverse and similar to the backgrounds, existing medical image segmentation methods cannot achieve satisfactory performance.However, it remains unclear whether various non-COVID19 lung lesions could contribute to segmenting COVID-19 infection areas and how to better conduct this transfer procedure.Amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, researchers have explored and proposed the use of said deep models to detect COVID-19 infections from radiographs as a possible way to help ease the strain on medical resources.However, pure manual segmentation of CT images faces a serious challenge with the increase of suspected cases, resulting in urgent requirements for accurate and automatic segmentation of COVID-19 infections.However, publicly available COVID-19 imaging data is limited which leads to overfitting of traditional approaches.
